After two years of very difficult negotiations and 12 months of armed peace, the war formally ended in December 1992 and a peaceful political situation was established. With regard to market discipline, the Government of El Salvador (GOES) launched a comprehensive macroeconomic reform program in 1989 supported by the IMF and the Bank (Structural Adjustment Loan (SAL) 1, 1991) which renewed growth from 1.1 % in 1989 to 3.4% in 1990, 3.5% in 1991, 4.6% in 1992, 5.1 % in 1993 and 5.8% (provisionally) in 1994, and reduced inflation (see para 1.2). Social programs to alleviate poverty have improved employment rates and increased real minimum wages by around 70% over the period 1989-1993. 1.4 Recent Reforms. The second phase of the reform program is now underway, aiming to sustain and deepen the adjustment process. This phase is supported by the IMF and the Bank, the latter through a US$50 million SAL 11 and a US$11 million Technical Assistance Loan (TAL), Loan 3389-ES, approved by the Bank in 1991. The reforms focus on: (a) modernizing the public sector; (b) fostering private sector export-led growth; (c) improving the efficiency of social services and reducing poverty; and (d) ensuring that development will be environmentally sustainable over the long term. The SAL also supports reforms in the petroleum sector including the elimination of price distortions and developing alternative systems of subsidies, and the preparation of a new hydrocarbons law. The TAL supports the preparation of a legal framework for protection of the environment. 1.5 Energy Sector Restructuring. As part of the reform effort, the government has begun an ambitious restructuring of the energy sector. In September 1991 it adopted an energy sector policy more consistent with the market-based economy being developed in El Salvador. Its four objectives were to: (a) create an appropriate legal and institutional framework for the sector; (b) adopt pricing policies and procedures based upon economic costs and market forces; (c) increase private sector participation in the energy sector; and (d) establish an institutional and policy framework to address environmental issues. To support this, the TAL has financed studies on the sector's legal and institutional framework, electricity pricing, the privatization of power distribution, and the liberalization of oil prices. Also funded were engineering studies to assess the best strategies for the rehabilitation, modernization and expansion of the power generation, transmission and distribution systems. These studies form the basis for the proposed project. The TAL has also financed the preparation of

II. THE ENERGY SECTOR A. Energy Resources and Consumption 2.1 Energy Resources. El Salvador's indigenous energy resources consist of hydropower and geothermal potential, bagasse and other biomass products. Hydroelectric potential is estimated at 1,600 MW, of which only 24% has so far been installed. Geothermal potential is estimated at 330 MW, but extensive field exploration is needed to assess its commercial viability. To date, 105 MW have been installed and about 60 MW are expected to be installed within the next ten years. No commercially exploitable oil or gas deposits have been identified and El Salvador continues to rely on imports of oil, mainly from Venezuela and Mexico, through the San Jose Agreement. 2.2 Energy Consumption and Losses. Economic growth in the last four years has accelerated the demand for energy and shifted consumption away from traditional forms of energy such as firewood. Total end-use energy consumption grew at 6% p.a. from 1989-1993, but firewood's share of the total declined by 17% and the share of petroleum and electricity increased by 4% and 2%, respectively. The share of total energy consumed by transport, industry and agriculture combined grew by 3.9% while that of commercial and residential sectors declined by 4%, reflecting the growth in the economy. In 1993, the residential and commercial sectors accounted for 54% of the total, followed by transport (22%), industry/agriculture (22%) and other (2%). 2.3 The chief energy source for Box 2.1: Energy Balance for El Salvador, domestic use is fuelwood, which 1993 accounted for 49 % of the total energy consumed in 1993. B. Organization and Management 2.5 The Ministry of Economy through the Directorate of Energy, Mines and Hydrocarbons (DEMH), regulates the hydrocarbons sector, while Comisi6n Ejecutiva Hidroelectrica del Rio Lempa (CEL), a government owned public utility, is in charge of the power sector, under the supervision of the Ministry of Economy. Annexes 2.1 and 2.2 show the organizational arrangements of the GOES and of CEL. In the past, the government exercised heavy control over the energy and power sectors. Until 1989, CEL formulated energy policy, planned development and issued regulations, spanning upstream activities in the petroleum subsector, hydrocarbon imports and fuel distribution, as well as the entire power sector. In 1990, with the creation of the DEMH, the government removed CEL's responsibilities to supervise activities related to petroleum products. 2.6 In spite of the reforms introduced in the last three years, public and private monopolies still dominate the energy sector in El Salvador. In the petroleum sector, the government holds a monopoly on crude oil imports. Firms wishing to import refined products require permits from the DEMH. In addition, DEMH regulates retail prices for petroleum products. The Oil Refinery of Acajutla (RASA) owned by ESSO (65%) and Shell (35%) has a de facto monopoly to import crude oil and refined products, except for those imported directly by CEL, since it has the country's only storage facilities and access to this has not yet been liberalized. 2.7 Within the power sector, CEL continues to operate as a vertically integrated monopoly. Until 1986, power distribution (except for rural areas) was in the hands of the private sector through concessions that finished that year. At that time, GOES bought the assets of the distribution companies and CEL became responsible for power distribution with the previously private sector concessions being administered by CEL, although they have been maintained in their original structure to facilitate their eventual reprivatization. CEL generates almost all the power supplied to the public grid. The Electric Power Company of El Salvador (CAESS), the main power distribution company, distributes electricity in the capital city and environs, representing 68% of the total retail consumption in 1994. The other six power companies and CEL account for 17% and 11% of the country's retail consumption respectively.

Sector Restructuring 2.11 In the Energy Sector Policy issued by the government in May 1991, and in further policy developments, it was determined that the following would be some of the main objectives of energy sector reform: (a) the power subsector would be liberalized and partly privatized; (b) the distribution companies would be transferred to the private sector; and (c) the petroleum subsector, currently operated by the private sector, would be further deregulated, monopolies broken up, and the remaining fuel subsidy eliminated. Legislation embodying these principles was
 6 presented to the Legislative Assembly in April 1995, aiming to foster competition, eliminate inefficient regulation and reduce government intervention in the business functions of the publicly-owned entities. The marginal cost and tariff study carried out by CEL in 1993, funded by the Bank Power Sector TAL, defined tariff adjustment mechanisms to meet marginal costs and to offset inflation and exchange rate variations. The study also delineated tariff regulations for monopolistic activities (transmission rates and retail distribution sales). The new legislation incorporates these mechanisms and principles. The inter-governmental coordinating body, Unidad Estudios Sectoriales (UES) is responsible for executing the studies funded by the TAL. UES is composed of representatives of the Ministries of Planning and Economy and of CEL. Under the proposed project, UES will assist in the execution of the technical assistance components. 2.12 The GOES presented to the Legislative Assembly in April 1995 three laws related to the electricity sector: the Electricity Law, and the legislation to establish, respectively, the National Energy Council (NEC) and the Electricity and Hydrocarbons Regulatory Commission (EHRC), the proposed planning and regulatory bodies for the sector. The Hydrocarbons Law has already been presented to Congress. The Electricity Law separates planning, regulatory and operating functions in the power sector, and ensures open access of power generators to the national interconnected grid and distribution networks. In addition, it establishes the procedures for IPPs participation in bidding to supply energy to power distribution companies (and others) and for regulating retail prices. It also calls for environmental assessments of proposed projects and proof of project clearance by the appropriate environmental authority as part of sector licensing requirements. The proposed NEC and EHRC Laws establish responsibilities, organization and financing procedures for the functioning of these entities. The new legislation will also establish a concession regime that will define the private sector's responsibilities. The GOES is strongly committed to the legislation, which is expected to pass through Congress later in the year. As evidence of this commitment to reform, in 1994 Congress approved legislation permitting the privatization of distribution, and CEL presented on April 4, 1995, a time-bound plan for their privatization to the President of El Salvador (the plan is known as the Power Distribution Plan, or Plan Integral de Gestion del Servicio Publico de Distribucion de Energia Electrica). CEL has already contracted to purchase 80 MW from an American independent power producer, due to start operation in late 1995. 2.13 The Hydrocarbons Law will correct most of the inefficiencies of current policy, which discourages foreign investors from exploration activities, and is the basis for the government monopoly for crude oil imports. The law will also improve conditions for competition, specify minimum technical and quality standards for petroleum products and introduce measures to protect the environment against oil spills and pollution. 2.14 When the new laws are enacted and with the entry of the private sector into the power subsector, a new generation and transmission planning scheme and a new regulatory framework will be in place. The proposed NEC and the EHRC would deal with planning and regulatory activities, respectively. NEC would be responsible for energy policy and indicative planning, currently assumed by CEL for power and the
 7 Ministry of Economy for petroleum. NEC would only perform indicative expansion planning. It would be composed of representatives of CEL, the Ministry of Planning, Ministry of Economy and Ministry of Agriculture. The responsibilities of NEC and EHRC will also include environmental quality control clearance of projects with regard to satisfaction of environmental guidelines and verification that licenses and authorizations have been obtained from appropriate authorities. 2.15 EHRC would be an independent entity with the power to regulate rates for transmission services and for the distribution companies. The latter would be based upon a benchmarking technique which would involve the estimation of the cost of service for an "efficient" distribution company, taking into account the consumer density and other factors specific to the service area. Charging for transmission services would be based upon an average cost methodology, allowing for the cost of capital and of operations and maintenance. Finally, EHRC would regulate prices charged for generation until the time at which it determines that the market for generation is competitive. After this point, prices for generation would be subject to negotiation between the generators and their customers which could include both distributors and final consumers of electricity. Until this time, generation costs would be calculated as the short run marginal costs of energy, as modelled by the EHRC and subject to discussion with generators and distributors, and the cost of peaking capacity. 2..16 Autonomy of the EHRC is expected to be achieved by rigorous qualifications and phased nominations of commissioners and by the requirement of both the Executive and Legislative authorities approval for appointments. EHRC would also authorize the operation of some types of power plants (geothermal, hydro and nuclear), and verify environmental and technical aspects of proposed projects and award power distribution concessions. In petroleum, EHRC would be mainly responsible for granting exploration concessions and regulating the price of refining activities as long as de facto monopoly conditions persist. 2.17 A Sectoral Environmental Assessment to be undertaken for the power sector (see paras. 4.13 - 4.15), which has been initiated prior to negotiations, will review the new environmental and energy sector laws and regulations and will recommend allocations of responsibilities among different agents in the power sector. It will propose: (a) environmental assessment guidelines for future projects; (b) pollution emission and ambient quality guidelines for future projects; and (c) management and control procedures to be followed during construction and operation of power facilities. In El Salvador, demand side management has not received the attention it warrants over the past decade, because of: (a) economic disruptions caused by the civil conflict; (b) the high priority assigned to containing damage to electricity supply system during the conflict; and (c) the supply orientation of the state monopoly. In electricity systems with serious quality and reliability problems, the most effective demand management instrument is pricing and billing/collection which the GOES has begun effectively using over the past two years. Significant progress has been made and is planned over the next three years with respect to tariff levels, their structure, and adjustment mechanisms to bring pricing into line with marginal costs of service (para. 2.10). These measures, together with improvements in commercial performance (ie reductions in non technical losses), provide strong incentives to consumers for efficient use of electricity. In addition, the government and CEL have prepared a program for energy conservation which focuses on developing and marketing energy efficient equipment for final users and for disseminating information on efficient use of energy more generally. The IDB project is providing technical and financial support for the implementation of this program. B. The Existing Power System 3.4 Installed Generating Capacity. In 1993 the installed public service capacity of the country (i.e. excluding industrial own-generation, of approximately 50 MW) was 833 MW. CEL's total installed capacity was 817.5 MW, of which 388 MW was hydro, 324.5 MW conventional thermal units and 105 MW geothermal plants. CAESS has 11.5 MW of hydro capacity; combined, the other distribution utilities own 4.4 MW of hydro capacity. In 1994 gross power generation amounted to 3146 GWh. 3.5 Generation, transmission and distribution facilities seriously deteriorated over the 1980s, due to sabotage and the continuous overloading of facilities to compensate. Plants were poorly maintained because the limited resources were used to repair sabotage damage, resulting in a low reliability of service and high voltage and frequency variations. The situation worsened in 1990-1992, due to the drought and the rapid increase in demand that occurred with economic recovery. As an emergency measure, CEL installed three gas turbines with a total capacity of 155 MW in 1993 and imported additional energy from Guatemala. Almost all thermal plant have now been rehabilitated, funded by IDB and international donors. Further, the Soyapango thermal plant is being repowered, financed by CEL's own funds and with commercial loans. The refurbishment of hydroelectric plants, including upgrading of technologically obsolete equipment, would be financed by the proposed project.
 10 3.6 The Transmission System. In the 1980s, there were over 2,000 attacks on substations and 3,800 on transmission lines, costing CEL about US$200 million. Repeated damage lead to temporary repairs and CEL had insufficient resources to follow up with permanent repairs. As a result, the current operation of the system is unreliable, and transmission losses have increased from 4% in 1986 to around 6% at present. Based on an engineering study funded by the Bank's TAL, the rehabilitation of the transmission system is underway, with financing from the IDB and the Overseas Economic Cooperation Fund (OECF) of Japan. 3.7 The Distribution System. Introduction 4.1 GOES of El Salvador is currently engaged in a comprehensive effort to increase its capacity to halt environmental degradation and improve management of its natural resources. Amongst other initiatives, the loans provide for the drafting of a National Environmental Law, preparation of a National Environmental Strategy and Action Plan, and redefinition of the role, position and internal organization of the National Council for the Environment (CONAMA) and its Executive Secretariat (SEMA). Institutional and Regulatory Framework 4.2 SEMA's draft organic law defines the agency's role and organization, as well as its relation to other public sector entities, such as CEL, whose operations have significant environmental impacts. In the proposed institutional structure, all such entities would participate in a committee of sectoral environmental units. Draft environmental impact assessment (EIA) guidelines, which list the main elements (such as screening criteria, project review requirements and procedures throughout the project cycle) are already available and will be approved in 1995. Although work on emission standards is included in the IDB project, authorities are giving more priority to preparation of norms on water quality. Thus, it is unlikely that air pollution stan- dards, which are directly linked to the operation of thermal power plants, will be available shortly. Organization and Management 5.1 Oversight of CEL's operations is the responsibility of the Ministry of Economy, though with the significant involvement of other ministries. External borrowing is approved by the Ministry of Planning, the annual budget by the Ministry of Finance and rate increases by the Ministry of Economy. The President of the eight member Board of Directors is appointed by the Minister of the Interior. The Board approves major investment plans, borrowing proposals and corporate policies, and recommends tariff changes to the government. 5.2 CEL's financial management is the responsibility of the Finance Department, which is headed by the Financial Director. Accounting and control functions are well developed. Current policies and procedures are weighted to controlling cash operating budgets and satisfying the reporting requirements of the Corte de Cuentas (Court of Accounts). Internal auditing supports these control procedures by carrying out ex-ante audits of expenditures. Other financial management functions are less well developed. Treasury functions are non-existent, as are general asset and liability management. Cash management, investments, and risk and exposure analysis are undertaken in only a limited way. Some financial management systems are under development, e.g. fixed assets, inventory and management accounting. B. Financial Performance 5.3 Past performance. (See Annex 5.2 for details) During the 1980s and early 1990s, CEL encountered operating difficulties that led to significantly diminished financial performance. Real average tariffs declined throughout the 1980s. The civil strife caused severe damage to transmission installations, devaluations of the colon added to the burden of servicing CEL's long-term debt and reduced earnings, and in 1991 and 1992 fuel expenses increased nearly seven-fold over the previous two years as a result of a severe drought which restricted hydro generation. CEL also had prob- lems collecting revenue from the power distribution companies and other major clients, which led to deteriorating liquidity. As a result, during this period CEL relied heavily on short-term debt and revenues from the commercialization of imported petroleum to finance its operating and capital budgets, and on central government transfers to remain solvent. The government restructured CEL's long term debt in 1990, helped settle overdue accounts receivable from the distribution companies and assumed its debt service obligations to the international financial institutions.
 16 Additionally, the government financed oil purchases in 1991 and 1992, and peri- odically provided interest-free, short-term working capital loans. 5.4 By the start of the decade, the government had recognized that tariff adjustments were essential to CEL's financial recovery. Thus, in 1991 and 1992 rates were increased significantly though their impact on net income was masked by the dramatic increase in fuel purchases due to the prolonged drought. A modest profit was recorded in 1994. Other signs of an improved financial situation have emerged in recent years: income from operations has increased significantly, and liquidity has im- proved due to better internal cash generation and the mobilization of external loans. The government is committed to continue to address the tariff issue and has agreed, under the terms of a loan with the Inter-American Development Bank, to increase tariffs to reach 85% of LRMC by 1996, and, under an agreement with the Bank for this project, to raise tariffs to 100% of LRMC by 1999. Bringing rates into line with LRMC, though it will require annual increases over the next five years, will address the most immediate financial needs of CEL (see para. 5.9 and Annex 5.5). 5.5 Projections. Based on these tariff assumptions, and projections of growth in demand and improved operating efficiency, CEL's finances will improve steadily from 1995 to 1999. Enhanced profitability will yield an average annual rate of return on net fixed assets of 7% (Table 5.1). Demand is expected to increase from 2,816 GWh in 1994 to 3,605 GWh in 1999, an average annual growth rate of about 5%. CEL's operating expenses will shift also, with a greater reliance on purchased power. Also, in 1994 the government instituted a value added tax that, for CEL, currently functions as an additional operating expense. CEL is obliged to pay the tax but is unable to pass it on to its clients'. CEL's improved profit margins and the magnitude of the payments allow it to absorb the impact of the tax. However it is petitioning the government to redress the situation. The favorable profit projections will also lead to a considerably strengthened financial structure. Total assets will expand rapidly in the initial years, principally due to additions to the physical plant; overall, total assets will grow by 15% per year through 1999. Shareholder equity, which was negative in 1990, will grow by about 12% per year during 1995-1999. Government additions to shareholder equity will end in 1995. The overall flow of funds will improve gradually but the composition will shift away from government support and towards greater internal cash generation and loans. 5.6 Financial management efficiency indicators will improve. CEL expects its collection rate on accounts receivable will drop to 40 days in 1995 and decline gradually thereafter. This target seems optimistic, but because CEL has reached agreement on the resolution of longstanding amounts due from the distribution companies and is essentially a wholesaler of power, an improved accounts receivable collection rate is well within its capacity. Inventory turnover has also improved, from 187 days in 1989 to 59 days in 1994, and is forecast to remain in this region through to 1999. 1. VAT is also currently not applied to water, sewerage, financial services, and the bulk of construction activities. Broadening the VAT base is part of a wider dialogue on taxation revenue issues being conducted between the Bank and GOES.

Most of the foreign cost components of the investments will be financed by external borrowing, through multilateral and bilateral agencies. Though the level of external debt is projected to increase significantly over the next five years, it is within CEL's capacity to incur this debt due to higher profits and internal cash generation. Its debt management indicators are within the targets of the Performance Plan agreed with the Bank (see para. 6.19 and Annex 5.4). CEL's current long term debt is most- ly held by development banks, with an average cost of just under 7%, on fixed terms and with an average maturity of 18 years. Future borrowing is expected to be on similar terms, except for a shift to variable interest rates. The investment program, however, includes some projects that may be financed by the private sector (in generation) and an allowance (around 5%) for investment in rural distribution networks. Under the new framework for the distribution sector, the government may make direct contributions to the expansion of distribution networks in areas that are not commercially attractive and it is therefore unlikely to continue to be an obligation that CEL will bear. For these reasons the investment program should be considered a pessimistic estimate of the investments that CEL will undertake, and one that could be curtailed in the event of an unexpected decline in internal cash generation. Although CEL's risk- management strategies are still relatively undeveloped, these risks can be mitigated and CEL has initiated discussions with an international commercial bank on the management of financial risks. In addition, CEL's modernization of existing capacity will significantly enhance efficiency and contribute to greater profit margins, thus providing more capacity to absorb risks. CEL's own financial structure carries three additional elements of risk: (a) interest rates. More than half the value of the long term debt will be on variable terms by 1995 and a 1 % increase in interest rates would cause net income to drop by 2%; (b) exchange rates. CEL's financial projections take into account currency devaluations on the order of 3 % -4% per year. A further 5 % devaluation of the colon in any year during the projection period would reduce income by about 3%; and (c) fuel supply. Recognizing this, CEL has managed to somewhat stabilize fuel purchases through an annual contract with a local supplier. While the price is about 30% greater than the average import price, it is significantly less volatile than the prices CEL paid for imported diesel fuel. Many power companies have a similar risk structure, especially when revenues are not denominated in the same currency as borrowings and fuel purchases. In the case of CEL, risks of this magnitude are manageable in the light of it's projected improved financial structure. In the event of much larger swings in interest rates, exchange rates or fuel prices, CEL would have to curtail its investment program to offset these impacts. The Bank will be reviewing progress on implementation of the investment program under the project. 5.9 At the sector level, the introduction of IPPs adds a competitive risk previously unknown to the power sector in El Salvador. A failure to attract IPPs could mean higher investments for CEL (paras. 5.5 and 5.7). Without sufficient resources, this could delay the construction of generating capacity and thus translate into CEL making expensive energy purchases or shedding load. Private sector interest in the sector has been high, however, and the first contract with an IPP has been signed (see para. 2.12). In the event of a deterioration in interest by the private sector, CEL may need to adjust its investment program. However, the new IPPs (additional to those envisaged being undertaken by the private sector in CEL's expansion program, see Annex 5.1) are relatively far in the future (see Annex 5.3). CEL would therefore have the opportunity to revise its investment program to accomodate the new investment requirements. Another possibility is that highly successful IPPs could win market share, and leave CEL with excess capacity and diminished rates of return. However, this risk is low because CEL's generation is mainly from hydro and geothermal plants, which have small incremental cost and should be priority dispatched. A second external risk is that posed by a delay or outright cancellation of tariff increases. Without such increases, CEL's rates of return would be unacceptable and its long term viability in doubt. A failure to increase tariffs above present levels would turn CEL's finances negative, leading to average annual rates of return of -1 % over the next five years. Under this situation, CEL's long term expansion plan would not be viable. A one-year delay in the implementation of tariff targets would reduce annual profits over 1995-1999 by one third. This could lead to CEL reducing the scale of its investment program. The recently-elected government, however, has declared it commitment to continued tariff adjustments (para 5.4) and reform of the sector.

VIl. PROJECT JUSTIFICATION A. Rationale for Bank Involvement 7.1 Efficient development of the power sector is critical for the future of El Salvador's economy. The Bank is uniquely placed to provide the support needed as a result of the work undertaken on the Power Sector TAL. The proposed project would help El Salvador: (a) increase power sector efficiency by refurbishing existing facilities, allowing the system to serve consumers that are currently without electricity; (b) continue legal and institutional reforms in the energy sector; and (c) undertake engineering studies for future projects. The technical assistance components related to energy and power sector restructuring will only go forward if the relevant legislation (Electricity Law, EHRC Law and NEC Law) is passed and the EHRC and NEC are established to the Bank's satisfaction. However, the Bank's involvement in the sector via this project would be justified in the event that these technical assistance components (which represent around 4% of project costs) do not go forward, because of the great need for investment to modernize and rehabilitate existing generation facilities. 7.2 The country assistance strategy (CAS) was discussed in conjunction with the Board presentation of the SAL II on September 17, 1993. The proposed project is fully consistent with the CAS and the Bank's strategy for lending operations in the energy sector. The project focuses on improving sectoral efficiency and the
 29 productivity of existing facilities, and expanding the role of the private sector. Bank presence is essential to help the government and CEL prepare legislation, restructure the sector and execute the privatization program. In addition, the Bank can play a catalytic role in securing and coordinating cofinancing for future operations, and reducing private investors' perceptions about risks. B. Project Benerits 7.3 The technical assistance components of the project can be expected to bring substantial benefits to the sector, in terms of strengthening the capabilities of CEL and other existing government entities involved in the energy sector, as well as providing support to the new bodies to be created under the GOES's legislative program and assisting the GOES in furthering the restructuring of the sector. In conjunction with the proposed project, CEL is undertaking a Sectoral Environmental Assessment, which will help introduce environmental considerations into management and planning activities in the sector. Although these benefits can be expected to be substantial, they have not been quantified. Economic appraisal has been undertaken for the (a) rehabilitation and modernization of the hydroelectric stations; and (b) addition of a third unit at Cerron Grande. The benefits of the modernization and rehabilitation of the telecommunications and information systems are not quantified given the inherent difficulties and uncertainties in this. Annex 7.1 presents the assumptions and working details for the economic analysis. 7.4 As far as the 1995-1999 time slice of the Power Sector Investment Program is concerned, expansion of the power system would allow the connection of an additional 185,000 consumers by 1999, so that 68% of the population (4.2 million) will have access to electricity compared to 61 % in 1993. The rehabilitation of existing facilities would reduce network losses and improve generating plant efficiency, allowing some additional energy to be served without increasing production. Finally, rehabilitation and expansion of the system will also improve the reliability and quality of service, reducing the incidence of unserved energy. The investments in this program are part of the least cost expansion plan for the system (see Annex 3.5 and paras. 3.8 and 3.9), modified to include the expansion of Cerron Grande. Project Risks 7.12 The investment components of the project, rehabilitation and expansion of hydroelectric and modernization of the telecommunications and information systems do not contain any unusual technical difficulties. Risks of slow implementation will be mitigated by the requirement that CEL appoint a Project Director to head a Project Implementation Unit (paragraph 8.2) to ensure smooth project implementation. Although the GOES is strongly committed to the legislative program (Electricity Law, NEC Law and EHRC Law), there is a possibility that the laws may not achieve passage through Congress in a manner acceptable to the Bank. Under the project, passage of the legislation and taking of the necessary subsequent actions for the establishment of the NEC and EHRC will be conditions for disbursement against expenditure for all technical assistance components related to energy and power sector restructuring (see para. 8.6). The legislative package has been developed in extensive consultation with the Bank, and the GOES's commitment to sector reform reduce the risk that the package will not be passed in an acceptable form. The legislation is part of wider sectoral reforms (see para. 7.14). 7.13 The main risk to viable economic returns for the rehabilitation and modernization of the existing hydroelectric stations is that the increase in output attributable to the rehabilitations will not be as high as anticipated. Sensitivity analysis (see Table 7.1) shows that this is a concern for the smallest plant, Guajoyo (representing 6% of the capacity being rehabilitated and modernized under the project). This in turn is most likely to be caused by inadequate maintenance which would reduce overall plant availability. However overall plant availability would have
 33 to fall substantially in order to produce large reductions in the anticipated increase in output (para. 7.8). On the financial side, the main risk is that tariff increases will not be implemented as planned (see para. 5.9). If tariffs are not increased from present levels, then CEL would face increasing losses over the next five years and be unable to fund its planned investment program. A slippage of one year of the planned tariff increases would reduce profits and force CEL to delay part of the investment program. If the tariff increases are applied as planned, then CEL will enjoy increased profit margins; although its external debt is forecast to rise substantially, CEL's higher profit and internal cash generation will allow it to bear this increased debt. The Government's commitment to aligning tariffs with marginal costs, as shown by the recent tariff increases (see para. 2.9) and by agreements reached under this loan (see para. 5.4) reduce the extent of this risk. The Bank will be reviewing CEL's investment plan on a semi-annual basis (see para. 8.4). Beyond the risks associated with tariffs, CEL, like other electric power utilities, must manage risks related to currency and interest rates and fuel supply costs. These risks, however, will be manageable with higher projected profit margins and better cash generation and through strengthened financial risk management procedures (see paras. 5.8 and 5.9). 7.14 As far as success in achieving the project objectives is concerned, the actions of GOES to date have shown that it is strongly committed to reform of the power sector and substantial progress has already been made. CEL has also contracted with an independent power producer for 80 MW of power, due to be on-line by mid 1995. CEL, working with the consultants MONENCO-Agra Inc., has developed a least cost expansion plan for the El Salvador power system for the period 1995 to 2010 (see Annex 9.1). The plan, which takes as its starting point the forecasts of sales, losses and energy and power requirements presented in Annex 3.4, was developed using the generation expansion model SUPER which uses a probabilistic approach. Under the base case forecasts, energy requirements are expected to grow at 4.8% from 1995 to 2000, and thereafter at 4.7%. An expected improvement in the load factor over the period to 2000 results in a lower forecast growth in power requirements (4.1 %) in the first five years of the plan. 2. Existing Capacity. Out of existing installed capacity of 817.5 MW on the interconnected system, available capacity is at present 704 MW. Of this, 278 MW (40%) is thermal capacity, 378 MW (54%) in hydroelectric with the remainder being geothermal (48 MW, or 7%). CEL is currently undertaking a program of rehabilitation and modernization of a number of its existing facilities; this will add 97 MW of firm capacity to the system. The schedule for this, along with the expected addition of capacity is as follows: 1995 Repowering of Soyapongo Gas Turbine 55 MW Stabilization of Ahuachapan I (Geothermal) 5 MW 1996 Stabilization of Ahuachapan 2 (Geothermal) 7 MW Rehabilitation of Acajutla 1&2 (Steam) - 1997 Stabilization of Ahuachapan 3 (Geothermal) 10 MW 1998 Stabilization of Ahuachapan 4 (Geothermal) 20 MW In addition, CEL has contracted to purchase 80 MW from an independent power producer, Nejapa Power, scheduled to start production in late 1995. 3. Candidate Plants. The following options were considered as candidate plant: a. Hydroelectric: expansion of 5 de Noviembre (120 MW) and Cerron Grande (67.5 MW); new schemes at El Tigre (351 MW), Paso del Oso (74 MW); San Marcos (56 MW) and Zapotillo (103 MW); b. Geothermal: Berlin - option of 2 x 27.5 MW or I x 55 MW; Berlin Phase 11 (27.5 MW); San Vicente (27.5 MW), the latter representing a new site; c. Thermal: Coal-Fired Steam (75 MW, 100 MW and 150 MW units); Oil-Fired Steam (75 MW, 100 MW and 150 MW units); Combined Cycle at Acajutla (110 MW); Combined Cycle options of 115 MW and 150 MW; Diesel Units of 60 MW (medium and low speed); d. Gas Turbine: units of 35MW, 80 MW and 100 MW.
 - 45 - Annex 3.5 Page 2 of 3 For each of these, assumptions regarding capital costs, operations and maintenance costs and operating efficiency were developed. These are described in greater detail in the report prepared by MONENCO-Agra Inc., "Actualizacion del Plan de Expansion del Sistem de Generacion" (see Annex 9.1). 4. Additional Planning Assumptions: a. Fuel Price Projections: the World Bank projections (dated June 1994) of international coal and oil prices were used in the study; b. Value of Unserved Energy: in the range of 0% - 2% the cost used is US$0.35/kWh; above this level, a value of US$0.80/kWh was used; this reflects the greater economic disruption associated with an increased volume of unserved energy; c. Quantity of Unserved Energy: the plan was developed so that on average unserved energy would represent less than 1 % of net generation; d. Reserve Margin over Peak Demand: although this criteria was not used explicitly in the modelling, CEL would typically ensure that the expansion plan provided a firm reserve margin of at least 20% over peak demand. 5. Least Cost Expansion Plan. The least cost expansion plan is shown in Table A3.2. Of the hydroelectric candidates, only the expansion of the 5 de Noviembre scheme is selected for the plan. Expansion of the geothermal system (Berlin - 2 x 27.5 MW) is envisaged as well, but the bulk of capacity additions are envisaged to be coal-fired steam units of 150 MW. On the basis of preliminary studies of hydrology, output and cost, the new hydro schemes in 3.a. above were not selected as part of the least cost plan. However, it is possible that they would be part of the expansion program with a more accurate definition of their potential and costs. Accordingly, the proposed Energy Sector Modernization Project (ESMP) would fund feasibility studies for two of the most promising hydro schemes in 3.a. above. This may lead to a redefinition of their costs and output, and based on this, subsequent expansion studies might select these plant as part of a least cost expansion program. 6. Expansion Plan with Cerron Grande Unit 3. The addition of a third unit at Cerron Grande does not appear in the strict least cost expansion plan. However, this project would provide the system with additional peaking capacity and reserve, and would provide insurance against delays in other projects selected for the expansion plan. The civil works for the third unit at Cerron Grande are already in place, having been completed as part of an earlier phase of development. CEL has undertaken a comparison, using the SUPER model, of the costs of system expansion with and without the Cerron Grande Unit 3 in 1998, presented in Table A3. 1. This shows that the inclusion of this scheme would produce savings in system operating cost and the expected cost of unserved energy that would almost outweigh the capital costs of the scheme, the increase in total expansion costs therefore being less than 0.4%. This, combined with the simplicity of the project and the insurance it would provide against delays in the envisaged least cost expansion scheme, indicate that the addition of the third unit at Cerron Grande would assist in making the expansion plan more robust. It is intended that the proposed ESMP finance the expansion of Cerron Grande.

Tariffs, exchange rates, interest rates, and power purchase agreements with IPPs each pose financial risks for CEL during 1994-1998. The exposure they create could affect income, cash flow and financial structure. However, the new structure in the power sector will provide CEL with the opportunity to manage its risks. For example, during the period in which the ERC sets prices, CEL's financial risks can be passed on to consumers in the form of higher rates. Once prices are market determined, CEL may not be able to do this and must thus be prepared to manage these risks. Although CEL's risk-management strategies are still relatively undeveloped, some discussions have taken place with an international commercial bank to identify potential actions. In addition, as it modernizes existing capacity, this will significantly enhance efficiency and contribute to greater profit margins, thus providing more capacity to absorb risks. 2. Tariffs Risk. CEL's most critical financial risk, which depends entirely on government action, is associated with a delay or outright cancellation of tariff increases. The latter would turn CEL's finances decidedly negative, increasing losses over the next five years and leading to average annual rates of return of about -1 %. Under these circumstances, CEL's long term expansion plan would not be viable. A one-year delay would reduce projected annual profits over 1995-99 by one third, and lead to an average annual rate of return of only 5%. However, this risk is unlikely because the former government has already authorized a rate increase and the recently-elected government has declared it will continue to liberalize the economy. 3. doc.abstracts: The Energy Sector Modernization Project will: (a) improve service reliability and increase coverage by rehabilitating, modernizing and expanding power generation, transmission, subtransmission and distribution systems; and (b) assist in the restructuring of the sector's legal and regulatory framework through the preparation of secondary legislation and procedures, and to support the Electricity and Hydrocarbons Regulatory Commission (EHRC) and the National Energy Council (NEC) when their respective laws are enacted. At the same time the government is introducing policies to promote environmentally sound investments and operating procedures by establishing project guidelines and quality standards and by strengthening management and enforcement capacities.
